we have a regional outage which is very
rare for an aws region to go down
but uh should it happen right oh just
which is basically the disaster recovery
situation
and let's say there is a regional outage
then what do you do
right there are some steps that we
recommend you follow
the first thing is your application
should stop writing to your primary
region
because again that region is not
available because of which you want to
do
you know disaster recovery set process
and uh use another region right so your
application should stop
writing to that primary region
and then uh you select one of the
secondary regions
that you want to promote to a primary
right and how you select this is going
to be based on where your users are
and you know which cluster will have a
better latency for them right let's say
our users are predominantly based out of
u.s so maybe in this case
uh you know frankfurt would be a better
choice because you are going to navigate
these users or route them to frankfurt
because this region is down so just pick
the region that is closer to your users
so that the latency is lower
and you know trigger the the failure
process
and also as a best practice we recommend
that you
remove all the other regions that are a
part of this global cluster as well
because
the applications that are connecting to
for example secondary region two in this
case
would still be able to read data from
that cluster because there's no outage
in that particular region and that
cluster is very much healthy
uh but it may so happen that you know
they are reading older data because the
primary region is down
and there's nobody replicating data to
this particular cluster
so to avoid data inconsistency issues
like that uh resulting from you know
no replication from a region that is
down it's always a best practice just to
remove those uh clusters from the global
cluster
